cards.front:
The electrical impulse of the heart normally begins at the:

A. Purkinje fibers.
B. sinoatrial node.
C. atrioventricular node.
D. bundle of His.
See The Circulatory System: Anatomy

The nose, chin, umbilicus (navel), and spine are examples of ___________ anatomic structures.

A. midline
B. midaxillary
C. proximal
D. superior
See Topographic Anatomy

Oxygen and carbon dioxide pass across the alveolar membrane in the lungs through a process called:

A. ventilation.
B. breathing.
C. diffusion.
D. osmosis.
See The Respiratory System: Physiology

The most distal four spinal vertebrae, which are fused together, form the:

A. ischium.
B. coccyx.
C. ilium.
D. sacrum.
See The Skeletal System: Anatomy

White blood cells, which are also called leukocytes, function by:

A. carrying oxygen and other nutrients.
B. producing blood-clotting factors.
C. producing the bodyâ€™s erythrocytes.
D. protecting the body from infection.
See The Circulatory System: Anatomy

The muscle tissue of the heart is called the:

A. epicardium.
B. pericardium.
C. endocardium.
D. myocardium.
See The Circulatory System: Anatomy

The left side of the heart receives oxygenated blood from the lungs through the:

A. pulmonary arteries.
B. inferior venae cavae.
C. superior venae cavae.
D. pulmonary veins.
See The Circulatory System: Anatomy

The central nervous system is composed of the:

A. brain and spinal cord.
B. brain and sensory nerves.
C. motor and sensory nerves.
D. spinal cord and sensory nerves.
See The Nervous System: Anatomy and Physiology

The axial skeleton is composed of the:

A. skull, face, thorax, and vertebral column.
B. bones that constitute the pelvic girdle.
C. lower part of the torso and the legs.
D. arms, legs, and pelvis.
See The Skeletal System: Anatomy
cards.back: skull, face, thorax, and vertebral column.

cards.front:
All critical life functions are coordinated in which part of the brain?

A. Cerebellum
B. Brainstem
C. Gray matter
D. Cerebrum
See The Nervous System: Anatomy and Physiology

Dead space is the portion of the respiratory system that:

A. must be filled with air before gas exchange can take place.
B. receives oxygen but is unable to release carbon dioxide.
C. includes the alveoli and capillaries surrounding the alveoli.
D. contains no alveoli and does not participate in gas exchange.
See The Respiratory System: Physiology
cards.back: contains no alveoli and does not participate in gas exchange.

cards.front:
The elbow is an example of a ____________ joint.

A. ball-and-socket
B. hinge
C. saddle
D. gliding
See The Skeletal System: Anatomy

As the bronchus divides into smaller bronchioles, the terminal ends of these smaller passages form the:

A. bronchi.
B. capillaries.
C. pleura.
D. alveoli.
See The Respiratory System: Anatomy

Which of the following glands regulates the function of all other endocrine glands in the body?

A. Thyroid
B. Adrenal
C. Parathyroid
D. Pituitary
See The Endocrine System: Anatomy and Physiology

The exchange of oxygen and nutrients for waste products of metabolism occurs at the cellular level in the:

A. arteries.
B. arterioles.
C. capillaries.
D. venules.
See The Circulatory System: Anatomy

Key hormones of the sympathetic nervous system include:

A. glucagon and noradrenaline.
B. acetylcholine and insulin.
C. norepinephrine and acetylcholine.
D. epinephrine and norepinephrine.
See The Circulatory System: Physiology

Which of the following organs or structures lies within the retroperitoneal space?

A. Kidneys
B. Spleen
C. Ascending aorta
D. Gallbladder
See The Digestive System: Anatomy

The carpal bones form the:

A. wrist.
B. ankle.
C. foot.
D. hand.
See The Skeletal System: Anatomy

Which of the following is not a facial bone?

A. Zygoma
B. Mandible
C. Maxilla
D. Mastoid
See The Skeletal System: Anatomy

Skeletal muscle is also called:

A. autonomic muscle.
B. voluntary muscle.
C. smooth muscle.
D. involuntary muscle.
See The Musculoskeletal System: Anatomy
